newsitem.title: UK: PPL Therapeutics studies animal transplants.
newsitem.headline: PPL Therapeutics studies animal transplants.

text.p: A research programme aimed at improving prospects for transplanting animal organs into humans was unveiled on Monday by Scottish genetics and proteins specialist PPL Therapeutics Plc.

Research will focus initially on heart transplants using genetically-modified pig organs. Shortages of human donors, with many patients dying before suitable organs are found, have led scientists to look at animals as an alternative.
PPL said in a statement it will invest at least 1.5 million pounds in a joint research effort with RPMS Technology Ltd, an arm of London's Royal Postgraduate Medical School.

Areas to be studied include molecular engineering of pig cells to reduce the likelihood of organ rejection by patients and the creation of genetically-altered animals suitable for providing transplant organs.

"Such use of organs on demand could have major impact in treating end-stage kidney and heart failure," said PPL, which specialises in producing human proteins for use in diseases like cystic fibrosis.
PPL managing director Ron James said "we are convinced that this is the way forward to make effective transplant therapies available to the largest number of patients needing them."

Scientists in the USA and elsewhere are working to solve a number of potential problems before animal-to-human transplants, know as xenotransplants, can become a reality. These include trying to stop animal diseases from being spread through the human population.
